subject: Home & DIY
title: Smart Locks: Convenience vs Security
description: A micro-lesson that makes Smart Locks: Convenience vs Security usable.

hook.text: Smart locks open with a phone, fingerprint, or code. No more hiding keys under the mat. But are they safer?

buildup.text: Benefits: temporary codes for guests, auto-lock when you leave, activity logs showing who entered and when.

discovery.text: Smart locks add digital risksâ€”Bluetooth sniffing, firmware exploitsâ€”but eliminate physical attacks like bump keys.

twist.text: Most smart locks keep a physical keyhole as backupâ€”ironically inheriting all traditional lock-picking vulnerabilities.

climax.text: The best smart locks use ANSI Grade 1 deadbolts with encrypted BLE or Matter. The mechanism outweighs the tech.

punchline.text: A smart lock on a weak door is security theater.

quiz.question: Why do most smart locks still include a physical keyhole?
options: As a backup in case of dead batteries or electronic failure
Building codes require a physical key entry option
To allow locksmiths to service the lock if needed
